definition: when things reach an extreme, they can only move in the opposite direction (idiom)
contrary/in reverse/inside out or upside down/to reverse/to return/to oppose/opposite/against/anti-/to rebel/to use analogy/instead/abbr. for 反切[fan3 qie4] phonetic system

sentences.english: I finally experience feeling of the old saying, " Too much water drowned the miller."
sentences.chinese: 我終於感受到那句俗話所說的感覺，“物極必反”。

sentences.english: But it can go too far.
sentences.chinese: 但是它也可能物極必反。

sentences.english: We don’t want to get too graphic here, but going overboard is kind of a turn off.
sentences.chinese: 我們不想要在這裏太過露骨，但物極必反。

sentences.english: Like ice cream, too much of the pulse at once is a bad thing.
sentences.chinese: 像冰激凌，一旦有太多的衝動，就會物極必反。

sentences.english: That things turn for the worse when they reach the extreme seems not to be something which people take heed of.
sentences.chinese: 物極必反的道理，似乎很難在人們心中起警惕的效應。

definition: man of Qǐ fears the sky falling (idiom); groundless fears
lit. to dispel the clouds and see the sun (idiom); fig. to restore justice
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
to dabble and stop (idiom); to dip into/to attempt half-heartedly/content with a smattering of knowledge
lit. one body two sides (idiom)/fig. a situation with two sides to it
to choose what is good and hold fast to it (idiom)
after hard work and numerous revisions (idiom)/the vicissitudes of life
